metadata.designer_notes: Authentic tension from real deadline conflict. Both roles challenging. Multiple valid negotiation paths.
metadata.authenticity_note: This scenario mirrors real workplace dynamics - manager has deadline pressure, team member has capacity constraints.

scenario.title: Negotiate Project Deadline
scenario.context: Team is asked to deliver a project sooner than expected. Team member must negotiate realistic timeline.

tension_trigger.trigger_description: Manager expects project next week (tight deadline). You know realistically it needs 3 weeks.
tension_trigger.source_of_authenticity: This is a real workplace scenario that occurs frequently. Not contrived.
tension_trigger.cognitive_pressure: Must respond to unexpected deadline without appearing unprepared or defensive.
tension_trigger.why_authentic: Real managers do propose unexpected deadlines. Real team members must negotiate. This is authentic communication need.

learner_role.name: Team Member
learner_role.goal: Negotiate realistic deadline (3 weeks ideal, minimum 2 weeks)
known_information: Project requires: 3 weeks for quality work
If rushed: Will result in bugs, technical debt
Relationship: Want to be seen as capable, but honest
constraints: Cannot shift blame to team (would seem like excusing)
learner_role.challenge_level: HIGH - Must assert needs while respecting hierarchy and maintaining relationship

partner_role.name: Manager
partner_role.goal: Push for faster completion if possible, but open to negotiation
known_information: Client deadline is next week (but could be flexible)
Not aware of team member's exact capacity
partner_role.challenge_level: MEDIUM - Facilitate negotiation, not resist. Play realistic manager, not antagonist.

role_design.power_dynamic_justification: Asymmetry requires learner to soften (can't be direct) and negotiate (can't refuse). Tests realistic communication.

learner_knows: Current workload: specific projects and tasks
Risk: Cutting corners = bugs, late-night stress
Value: Team member is experienced, knows this project type
partner_knows: Deadline is externally imposed (but actually flexible)
Team member is reliable (but doesn't know capacity)
Client is waiting (but not critical path)
information_asymmetry.creates_tension: Learner doesn't know manager's flexibility. Must propose realistic timeline based on own expertise, risking manager resistance.

dialogue_example.manager: I need this project completed next week.
dialogue_example.learner: To be honest, I'm concerned about the timeline. With our current workload, rushing this will create technical debt. What if we aimed for two weeks? That gives us time for quality work.

valid_solution_paths.description: Direct path - learner acknowledges tension, explains constraints, proposes solution immediately.

valid_solution_paths.path_name: Inquiry Path: Soften → Ask Questions → Understand → Propose

dialogue_example.manager: I need this project completed next week.
dialogue_example.learner: I appreciate the timeline you're thinking of. Can I ask - is that when the client needs it, or is there some flexibility?
dialogue_example.manager: Actually, we have some flexibility. The client asked for next week, but we could probably manage two weeks.
dialogue_example.learner: That's really helpful to know. Two weeks would give us time to do this right. Can we plan for that?

valid_solution_paths.description: Inquiry path - learner gathers information first, understands manager's real constraints, proposes timeline based on mutual understanding.

valid_solution_paths.path_name: Negotiation Path: Soften → Propose → Counteroffer → Compromise

dialogue_example.manager: I need this project completed next week.
dialogue_example.learner: I see your pressure. What if we aimed for two and a half weeks? That balances timeline and quality.
dialogue_example.manager: Can't you do it in one and a half weeks?
dialogue_example.learner: That's tight, but if we streamline the testing phase... we could try for two weeks. Would that work?

valid_solution_paths.description: Negotiation path - iterative back-and-forth until both parties reach compromise they can live with.

valid_solution_paths.path_name: Escalation Path: Soften → Ask → Escalate Decision

dialogue_example.manager: I need this project completed next week.
dialogue_example.learner: I understand the urgency. With our team size, one week is risky. Could we involve the director to see if we can adjust resources?

valid_solution_paths.description: Escalation path - if impasse reached, suggest involving higher authority professionally without hostility.

exit_conditions.description: Both agree on realistic deadline (2-3 weeks)
exit_conditions.learner_behavior: Has negotiated deadline confidently, maintained relationship, proposed realistic timeline
exit_conditions.observable_marker: Manager says 'OK, I understand, let's do 2 weeks' or 'That makes sense. Two weeks works.'

exit_conditions.description: Agreement to revisit decision after more analysis
exit_conditions.learner_behavior: Has defended timeline, asked for more time to prepare detailed plan
exit_conditions.partner_behavior: Agrees to defer decision, promises to discuss tomorrow
exit_conditions.observable_marker: Manager says 'Let me check with the client, we'll talk tomorrow' or 'OK, let's do an analysis and meet again'
exit_conditions.success_indicator: LEARNER AVOIDS rushed decision, buys time for better proposal

exit_conditions.learner_behavior: Has explained constraints clearly, professionally suggests escalation
exit_conditions.partner_behavior: Agrees that issue needs higher-level decision
exit_conditions.success_indicator: LEARNER PREVENTS bad outcome by escalating professionally

exit_conditions.description: Learner agrees to unrealistic deadline under pressure
exit_conditions.learner_behavior: Gets pushed into accepting 1-week deadline without strong negotiation
exit_conditions.observable_marker: Learner says 'OK, we'll try to make it work' without proposing realistic timeline
exit_conditions.success_indicator: LEARNER FAILS - accepted bad outcome due to insufficient softening/negotiation

essential.reason: Must respond to unexpected deadline without hostility or defensiveness
essential.intensity: HIGH - this is the foundation of everything else
example_chunks: I appreciate the timeline you're thinking of
essential.why_essential: Without softening, learner either agrees (bad outcome) or refuses (damages relationship). Must soften to negotiate.

essential.trigger: After softening, need to present alternative
essential.intensity: HIGH - this is the solution to the tension
example_chunks: What if we aimed for 2 weeks?
Could we try a different timeline?
essential.why_essential: Softening alone won't solve the problem. Must propose realistic alternative to reach agreement.

useful.reason: Understand manager's real constraints and flexibility
useful.trigger: If manager seems resistant to proposal
example_chunks: Can I ask - is that when the client needs it?
Is there flexibility on the deadline?
useful.why_useful: Helps learner gather information to make better proposal. Shows professional thinking.

useful.trigger: If manager seems frustrated or dismissive
example_chunks: I want to make sure we deliver something great
I'm not saying no, I'm saying let's be realistic
Let me rephrase - my concern is about quality
useful.why_useful: Prevents escalation. Keeps relationship intact while negotiating.

example_chunks: Could we involve the director on this?
Should we escalate this to higher level?
Maybe we need more context from leadership?
useful.why_useful: Allows professional exit from impasse without either party losing face.

avoid_triggering.reason: Would damage relationship and come across as insubordinate
Would undermine learner's credibility and expertise
Would make manager question learner's expertise

authenticity_validation.would_native_recognize: YES - This is an authentic workplace scenario
authenticity_validation.native_speaker_feedback: This is a real negotiation I have with my manager at least once a month. The tension is real, the communication strategies match workplace reality.
authenticity_validation.learner_assessment: This is authentic negotiation practice, not role play. Learner is developing real communicative competence.
authenticity_validation.cultural_appropriateness: Professional, British English context. Culturally authentic for workplace.

cognitive_load_analysis.stage_1: MODERATE - Learner recognizes tension and chooses softeners. Multiple choice reduces production demands.
cognitive_load_analysis.stage_2: MODERATE - Learner generates softeners, manager responds authentically. Still has word hints.
cognitive_load_analysis.stage_3: HIGH - Learner must manage tension AND propose solutions simultaneously. Minimal support.
cognitive_load_analysis.stage_4: HIGH - Learner navigates unrehearsed negotiation. Must adapt to manager's responses. No support.

integration_notes.for_chunk_curator: Focus vocabulary on softening phrases, alternative proposals, and clarifying questions. Register: professional but friendly.
integration_notes.for_system_builder: Priority 1 blanks: softening functions (To be honest, I see your point). Priority 2: proposal structures (What if we). Fade completely in Stage 4.
integration_notes.for_learning_architect: This task fully exercises all 3 learning outcomes. Softening required, repair may be needed, proposing always required.

has_tension_trigger.evidence: Manager wants 1 week, learner needs 3 weeks. Clear preference conflict.

tension_is_authentic.evidence: Native speakers confirm this scenario occurs regularly in real workplaces.

requires_negotiation.evidence: Task cannot be solved by yes/no response. Must negotiate compromise.

multiple_valid_paths.evidence: 4 distinct solution paths documented. All lead to authentic resolution.

exit_conditions_clear.evidence: Success, partial success, impasse, and failure all defined objectively.

pragmatic_functions_required.evidence: Softening and proposing are necessary for success. Not optional.
